issue.title: $foo instanceof $classString doesn't specialise $foo when $classString is generic

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

body:
Small nit: here the `@template-typeof` is redundant:

```
     * @template-typeof T $fooClass
     * @param class-string<T> $fooClass
```
Although this is identical to something we do at Vimeo, I don't think it's a common-enough use-case to warrant a separate type, sorry.

> Small nit: here the `@template-typeof` is redundant

Hmm yeah, I thought this too (I was updating some code to Psalm 3.4) so I removed it and got +60 errors so assumed it was still required :) I just tried my code in `master` and same thing happens so I'll have to track down a minimal example of what's causing that.

> Although this is identical to something we do at Vimeo[...]

I'd be curious to see how Vimeo has implemented it, do you just have some `@psalm-suppress` annotations to ignore the error? The trouble is, I can't think of a way of using existing annotations to tell Psalm what I'm doing with the array (and I kind of need the array to perform lookups) :)

Best way I can think of without suppressing the error is to utilise an `_ instanceof $fooClass` check (as in #1970). But apart from being unnecessary code in theory, it also then forces the case that that check fails to be dealt with as an additional code path.

Would be curious to see if Vimeo did anything different to one of these two?

issue.title: Generic support for key-value pairs

repository.name: phpstan
repository.description: PHP Static Analysis Tool - discover bugs in your code without running it!

issue.title: Unexpected InvalidReturnStatement with methods of generic classes calling out to methods returning static

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

body: This turns out to be a fairly common ask. Reopening.
Naming this type elsewhere (e.g. in a return type) could be problematic if the only way to notate this relationship is as a property accessor template?
Yeah - maybe it should be `class-string-map<T of Foo, T>`

issue.title: Array<class-string<T>, Generic<T>> incorrectly failing

repository.name: phpstan
repository.description: PHP Static Analysis Tool - discover bugs in your code without running it!

issue.body:
# Bug report
Arrays of [class-string => someObjectForClass] are complaining about incompatible keys and values despite the errors indicating that the types were correctly inferred.

```
| 31   | Array (array<class-string<T of object>, Generic<T of object>>) does not accept key class-string<T of object>.    |
| 31   | Array (array<class-string<T of object>, Generic<T of object>>) does not accept Generic<T of object>.             |
| 33   | Method Container::getThing() should return Generic<T of object> but returns Generic<T of object>|Generic<T of object>. |
```
### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

`T of object`
https://phpstan.org/r/45b50c90-1821-47fc-aedd-e4f91d5b5d1c

`T`
https://phpstan.org/r/fa7fb0a2-9546-4162-a4fc-c36529e0e2a1

### Expected output

OK/No errors

body:
> Yeah - maybe it should be `class-string-map<T of Foo, T>`

I think that's a good idea. Looking at the other threads it seems that wanting a class-string to map to a callable which returns that class is also a use case, which I hadn't considered.

I think the syntax you suggested here does a good job to accommodate arbitrary placement of the class-string type within the value position. This would definitely be a *new* syntax behaviour, where there's sort of an unspecialised generic passed through the type arguments, which doesn't really become specialised until call time (where the generic serves to preserve the type relationship until then).

It's almost as if we want `class-string-map` to here actually accept a type (say `T`) which forms the upper constraint, and a [type constructor (kind `* -> *`)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kind_(type_theory)) called `U<_>` say, which is then passed down to the array accessor which is itself a generic of the signature:

```php
/**
 * @template V as T
 * @param class-string<V> $tClass
 * @return U<V>|null
 */
public function get($tClass);
```

So something like the following if written as a class (of course in practice this would be a subtype of an array):

```php
/**
 * @template T
 * @template U<_>
 */
class class-string-map
{
    /**
     * @template V as T
     * @param class-string<V> $tClass
     * @return U<V>|null
     */
    public function get($tClass);
}
```

You'd then need some way of specifying this type constructor inline, perhaps using `_` again, e.g.: if you wanted to return a callable: `callable():_`. Full declaration: `class-string-map<Foo, callable():_>` would mean that a variable of this type accepts `class-string`'s which are `Foo` or a subtype, and returns a callable which maps to the corresponding `class-string`. Similarly, `class-string-map<Foo, _>` would mean that a variable of this type accepts `class-string`'s which are `Foo` or a subtype (as before), but returns an instance of the type corresponding to the given class-string.

Maybe this type of thing has been done elsewhere in another language, in which case it might be a good idea to lean on existing conventions?

I'm not sure there are similar constructs in other languages  I don't think Hack has one, for example (though @fredemmott may correct me).

The syntax I'm using [in my current working branch](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/compare/class-string-map) is

`class-string-map<T as ClassOrInterface, U>` where `U` is a type parameterised on `T`
e.g. `class-string-map<T, T>`, `class-string-map<T as Bar, Closure():T>`

I think it's the most obvious solution given how templated parameters are referenced today.

cc @TysonAndre @ondrejmirtes if they have other thoughts/opinions

Even if it occurs in various projects, it'd probably only occur in a few places within projects. Suppressing the issues or switching to a helper method or `MyFactory<class-string<T as Bar>, Closure(): T>` would be other options.

This might add additional work for conditionals, inferring types for access/foreach, plugins, etc., so those would continue to work properly, for a much less common use case than list/generic arrays/etc.

EDIT: P.S. I can't think of similar constructs elsewhere.
I've added a very basic implementation, but it's an obscure-enough use case that I don't think I'll do anymore work on it  anyone who wants to use it is responsible for fixing any bugs they find :)

issue.title: Template on a container not working correctly

repository.name: phpstan
repository.description: PHP Static Analysis Tool - discover bugs in your code without running it!

issue.body:
# Support question

I've put this as a support question as i'm 99% sure this is an error on my side.

A (simplified) version of the code snippet: https://phpstan.org/r/90b1c346-4eea-4c05-aa8a-b7c23e889325

Basically, why doesn't  phpstan understand that if `get` is called with `Foo::class` it will return an instance of `Foo`
